repnme.cdata!:
Gambia - Capacity Building for
            Environmental Management Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and the institutional development
            impact is modest. Lessons convey the following. Although the
            Bank, by and large, favored stand alone operations with
            limited financing for environmental capacity building, such
            as this one, given the usually weak in-country base, it is
            now suggested that it would be more appropriate to start
            with a larger operation, to be extended over a longer period
            of time. Thus, an adaptable program loan seems a more
            appropriate lending instrument. Despite donor
            community's awareness on the importance of Government
            ownership, it should be recognized that national
            institutions may not always have, neither the capacity, nor
            perhaps the interest to ensure effective donor coordination
            when faced with the realities of implementation, which can
            lead to inefficient allocation of human resources, and
            funds, as different donor initiatives compete for attention.
            Capacity building operations should assess training needs
            early on, based on manpower development plans prepared by
            experts, for while workshops provide the means for
            information dissemination, they only have marginal value as
            a means of training, and strengthening capacity. And,
            implementation capacity should be based on strong
            administrative systems, with carefully appraised management capacity.

18157402.subsc: Other social services,Law and justice,Central government administration
18157402.theme: Environmental policies and institutions,Other public sector governance
18157402.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Gambia - Capacity Building For
            Environmental Management Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Capacity Building for Environmental
            Management Technical Assistance Project consists of six
            major components: (a) institutional support for coordination
            of Gambia Environmental Action Plan (GEAP) Implementation,
            to support the National Environment Agency (NEA) to develop
            its operational capacity by financing equipment, training
            and targeted technical assistance. The development of
            management and technical skills in NEA and the provision of
            associated training in environmental management for staff of
            sector agencies and private sector operators, through
            short-term practical attachments or workshops; (b) GEAP
            monitoring and policy development, to reorient the existing
            sectoral policies and develop new policies where necessary,
            in accordance with the overall environmental policies
            elaborated in the GEAP; (c) environmental education and
            public awareness, to support the development of a strategy
            to increase public awareness of environmental issues and
            support for electronic and print media campaigns, using
            existing government and Non-Governmental Organization (NGO)
            skills and capacities. The last three components include:
            (d) monitoring of environmental quality, to support the
            development of a system to collect information and monitor
            environmental quality against agreed threshold levels; (e)
            environmental information management, to finance the
            development and implementation of an environmental
            information strategy according to a distributed model
            including: (i) the design of a common information
            architecture to establish coherence and compatibility; (ii)
            the establishment of basic information infrastructure; (iii)
            the maintenance of key data sets; and (iv) analytical
            capabilities; and (f) contingency planning and disaster
            preparedness, to develop a disaster awareness and
            contingency planning system.
